title: LO1: Positions and Distances
objectives: Associate a locus of points using distances to a vector expression using magnitudes.
Use linear combinations to specify positions in relation to one another.
Express linear interpolations and weighted averages as convex combinations.

title: LO2: the Products
objectives: Exploit the algebraic and geometric formulas of the dot product to:
compute said product.
calculate angles.
identify orthogonal vectors.
Relate scalar and vector projection to one another and interpret visually.
Use the formulas to determine if projection identities hold or have cournterexamples.

title: LO3: Lines & Planes
objectives:
Compute and articulate the direction and magnitude of the
                cross-product in terms of the inputs.

Demonstrate that both lines and planes (in dim 3) can be
                determined with 2 vectors.

Contrast the (prescriptive) parametric form with the
                (descriptive) equation forms of each.

Find intersections and generally solve problems of the form
                "Find the line plane that..."

Select the appropriate role of projection in distance problems
                between points, lines, and planes.

title: LO4: Intro to Curves
objectives: Parametrize simple curves such as lines, graphs, and circles.

Formulate the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus for vector-valued
                functions.

Identify position, velocity, speed, and acceleration using the
                machinery of vector-valued functions.

Solve initial-value motion problems with piecewise-defined
                acceleration functions.

title: LO5: Arc Length & Curvature
objectives: Compute the arc length of a fixes section of a curve.
Parametrize a curve by arc length
Compute and interpret curvature.

title: L06: Scalar Fields
objectives: Identify domains and images of functions of several variables.
Match formulas, graphs, and contour plots of scalar fields.
Sketch level sets for basic functions of 2 variables.

Identify continuous functions and compute limits for functions
                of 2 variables.

Express partial derivatives in limit form and compute them in
                arbitrary dimensions.
Verify Clairaut's Theorem in higher dimensions.
Interpret PDE's and verify (but not find) solutions.

Approximate partial derivatives given a contour plot and/or
                tabular data.

title: LO7: Linearization
objectives:
Determine (quickly) whether a functions of several variables is
                linear.

Identify the correct linearization formula for a given function
                and connect it to tangent lines/planes.

Identify an appropriate function and point to use linearization
                in estimating various quantities.

Use linearization and/or differentials to estimate error (and
                relative error.)

title: LO8: Chain Rule
objectives: Sketch a dependence tree for compositions.
Select the correct form of the chain rule for arbitrary compositions of scalar fields.
Compute higher order derivatives via the chain rule.
Implicitly find rates of change by reexpressing relations between quantities as level sets.

title: LO9: The Gradient
objectives:
Distinguish between the definition and the formula for
                directional derivatives.
Rattle off the 3 principal properties of the gradient.
Use the gradient to find tangent planes to level curves.
Given the gradient at a point, identify directions with rates.
Sketch a gradient field in 2 dimensions given a contour plot.

title: LO10: Local Extrema
objectives: Provide a technical definition of local extrema.
Identify critical points of scalar fields.

Give examples of each class of critical point in 2 and 3
                dimensions.
Correctly implement the 2nd derivative test in 2 dimensions.

title: L11: Optimization
objectives: Model an optimization problem by identifying:
the target function.
the variables and domain of feasibility.
any constraint functions.
Identify whether a domain is open, closed, or neither, and where for extrema.
Set up and solve systems of equations for the method of Lagrange multipliers.
Interpret the Lagrange equations geometrically.
Utilize the Extreme Value Theorem to find global minima and maxima.

title: L12: Integrals
objectives: Express a multiple integral as a limit of Riemann sums.
Detect syntactic errors in expressions of iterated integrals.
Set up iterated integrals (in 2 and 3 dimensions) for regions.
Given an iterated integral in 2 variables, sketch the region of integration and change the order.
Change the order of integration for iterated integrals in 3 dimensions for select cases.
Compute volumes and areas via multiple integration.

title: L13: Changing Coordinates
objectives:
Convert a specific point's coordinates between
                rectangular/cylindrical/spherical coordinates.

Convert a general expression in rectangular coordinates into
                cylindrical and spherical coordinates.

Select an appropriate coordinate system, convert, and compute
                for multiple integrals.
Explain the role of the Jacobian term in area/volume integrals.

Recognize and formulate expressions for planes, cones,
                cylinders, and spheres in various coordinate systems.

title: LO14: Applications of Integration
objectives:
Interpret a density function (in various dimensions) as a
                distribution or an indication of "where stuff is."

Correctly compute center of mass for various distributions,
                using symmetric arguments where appropriate.

Reason about and compare moments for different distributions
                without necessarily computing the numeric value.

Reinterpret basic probability questions about multiple random
                variables in terms of integrals.

title: LO15: Vector Fields & Path Integrals
objectives:
Sketch a vector field plot, and match a plot with its formula
                from a list.

Convert path integrals of each kind to 1-dimensional integrals
                via parametrization:w/ respect to arc length.w/ respect to individual coordinates.
w/ respect to arc length.
w/ respect to individual coordinates.

Identify which of these depend on orientation of the curve and
                how.

Estimate sign and/or magnitude of line integrals without direct
                computation.
Convert work problems into appropriate forms of line integrals.

title: LO16: Conservative Vector Fields & FTLI
objectives:
Interpret a line integral of a vector field as sum of line
                integrals of scalar fields.

Determine if a vector field is conservative and find a potential
                if so.
Recognize when and how to apply FTLI.
Equate path-independence with closed loops yielding 0.
Solve mechanical problems with conservative forces.

title: LO17: Green's Theorem
objectives: Verify the hypotheses of Green's Theorem.
Use Green's Theorem to compute areas in the plane.
Interpret the scalar curl as the spin of a vector field.
Utilize the flux form of Green's when appropriate.

title: LO18: Surfaces
objectives: Parameterize surfaces of 3 types:graphs of functions of 2 variables.surfaces of revolution.parts of spheres.
graphs of functions of 2 variables.
surfaces of revolution.
parts of spheres.
Compute surface area given a parameterized surface.
Integrate scalar fields with respect to surface area.

title: LO19: Flux
objectives:
Describe what it means for a surface to be oriented (and
                orientable).

Given a specified orientation of a surface, find a
                parametrization that is compatible.

Construct a flux integral as a double integral via
                parametrization.

Reason, without direct computation, about the sign or magnitude
                of a flux integral.
Compute the divergence and curl of a 3D vector field.

title: LO20: Stokes' Theorem
objectives:
Combine the "del" operations where well-defined and establish
                which yield zero.

Determine if a boundary curve is oriented positively relative to
                an oriented surface and vice versa.
State Stokes' Theorem and identify its necessary components.
Verify both sides of the equality in Stokes' in basic examples.

title: LO21: The Divergence Theorem
objectives:
State the Divergence Theorem and identify its necessary
                components.

Verify both sides of the equality in the Div Thm in basic
                examples.

Exploit the Divergence Theorem to compute flux through a
                not-necessarily closed surface.

Create a specific example in which both Stokes' and Divergence
                Theorems apply.
